metadata.title: Effect of stable antimicrobial nano-silver packaging on inhibiting mildew and in storage of rice

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Food Chemistry
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate / foodchem
Effect of stable antimicrobial nano-silver packaging on inhibiting mildew and in storage of rice
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.foodchem.2016.08.013 0308-8146/ 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail address: ccj33@163.com (C. Cao).
Li Li a, Chanjuan Zhao a, Yadong Zhang b, Jianfeng Yao c, Wenjian Yang a, Qiuhui Hu a, Cailin Wang b, Chongjiang Cao a,⇑ aCollege of Food Science and Engineering, Nanjing University of Finance & Economics, Nanjing 210023, China b Institute of Food Crops, Jiangsu Academy of Agricultural Sciences/Jiangsu High Quality Rice R & D Center, Nanjing 210014, China cCollege of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, China
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 22 February 2016 Received in revised form 5 August 2016 Accepted 6 August 2016 Available online 6 August 2016
Keywords: Rice Antimicrobial nano-silver packaging Storage Antimildew
a b s t r a c t
Antimicrobial nano-silver packaging (ANP) films were synthesized by blending polyethylene and highly dispersed Ag/TiO2 powder for rice storage at 37 C and 70% relative humidity. ANP films were characterized by X-ray diffraction and silver migration. The antimicrobial activity of the films was assessed on Aspergillus flavus (A. flavus) by scanning electron microscope and total plate count, and the storage quality of rice was evaluated by texture analyzer and rapid viscosity analyzer. The results show that ANP had a quite beneficial effect on the antimildew and physicochemical property as compared to the normal PE packaging. During 35 days storage, the migration of silver into rice was not evident. A lower microbial population is observed on ANP that should be attributed to the presence of Ag/TiO2. Furthermore, rice packed by ANP shows an enhanced quality with regards to texture and pasting properties. Therefore, ANP is a promising packaging material for rice storage.
2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Rice is one of the most widely consumed cereal foods in the world. To sustain consumer demand throughout the whole year or in case of emergency, a certain quantity of harvesting rice should be stored (Choi et al., 2015). However, during the storage period, the aging process starts immediately, leading to physicochemical changes that directly affect sensory qualities of rice (Gujral & Kumar, 2003; Helliwell, Blanchard, Zhou, & Robards, 2007; Toshihisa, Makoto, Kazuki, & Naganori, 2007). Many studies have been reported on the change in pasting properties, texture characteristic, nutrition and flavor of aged rice (Champagne et al., 1998; Zhou, Robards, Helliwell, & Blanchard, 2003). Moreover, it is important to control the microbiological quality of rice. The growth of some fungal species on rice will result in a microbiological safety concern, and this needs to be addressed (Kumar, Basu, & Rajendran, 2008; Reddy, Reddy, & Muralidharan, 2009). Aspergillus flavus can produce mycotoxins that are the major genera of fungi found on rice (Park, Choi, Hwang, & Kim, 2005).
Packaging is an important factor for rice preservation. Conventional packaging systems are designed to act as passive barrier (Bradley, Castle, & Chaudhry, 2011), protecting rice against the
surrounding environment. In recent years, nanocomposite food packages produced by incorporating nanoparticles of metal and meal oxide including silver, zinc oxide, titania and alumina (Llorens, Lloret, Picouet, Trbojevich, & Fernandez, 2012), have been used in several agricultural products (Abreu, Cruz, Angulo, & Losada, 2010), such as mushroom (Fang et al., 2015) and strawberry (Yang et al., 2010). Nanocomposite packages are supposed to inhibit or retard microbial growth and food spoilage in addition to acting as a passive barrier to external conditions. Polymers used for the fabrication of nanocomposites include polyethylene (PE), polypropylene, polyurethane and polyamide.
In recent years, great attention has been devoted to nanomaterials owing to their unique impact on a wide range of industries and markets (Pitkethly, 2004). Among various metal and metal oxide materials being used for nanocomposite food packaging, silver (Ag), and titania (TiO2) are particularly important. TiO2 is often used as an adsorbent, pigment or catalytic support because it is a semiconductor with great optical, electrical and photosensitive for its outstanding photo-induced oxidation and reduction characteristics (Eiden-Assmann, Widoniak, & Maret, 2004; Siwińska-Stefańska, Ciesielczyk, Nowacka, & Jesionowski, 2012; Xiaobo & Mao, 2007). It is commonly used in packaging as a photocatalytic antibacterial agent (Dariusz et al., 2007; Salabat, 2015; Zhou, Robards, Helliwell, & Blanchard, 2002). Ag has also attracted great interest owing to its photoactivity of semiconductor
photocatalysis, antibacterial activity and the presence of nanocrystallites (Zhao et al., 2012). Several studies have been reported to explain the antibacterial mechanism of silver. In general, silver can release silver ions from the silver particle (Marambio-Jones & Hoek, 2010) and bind to bacterial cell wall membrane, leading to the inactivation of the enzymes (Møretrø, Høiby-Pettersen, Halvorsen, & Langsrud, 2012). However, as silver is a heavy metal, it can cause toxicity and denature the proteins and enzymes in our body at a high concentration, the silver migration hazard should be evaluated.
In this study, a stable antimicrobial nano-silver packaging with a low silver migration was prepared by the addition of Ag/TiO2 powder, and the effect of the nano-silver packaging material on the antimildew and physicochemical properties of the rice during storage was investigated. This work provides promising technologies applicable to minimize the undesirable physicochemical changes andmildew of rice during storage andmaintain its quality.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Newly harvested paddy rice (crop year 2014, cultivar-Nanjng 9108) grown in Nanjing (Jiangsu, China) was obtained from Jiangsu Academy of Agricultural Sciences (JAAS). The newly harvested sample was sundried for 2 days to reduce the moisture content to15.5% before dehulling and polishing. TiO2 was purchased from Nanjing Dingbei biological technology Company, China. Attapulgite and SiO2 were purchased from Nanjing Haitai Nanotechnology Company, China. Low-Density Polyethylene (LDPE), linear low density polyethylene (LLDPE) was purchased from SinoecQilu Company, China.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of antimicrobial nano-silver packaging and normal packaging
sections.text:
Ag/TiO2 powder was prepared using a strong electrostatic adsorption method (Lambert et al., 2009). [Ag (NH3)2]+ was adsorbed onto TiO2 from an excess of solution at the pH with the strongest interaction. The masterbatch was obtained by mixing Ag/TiO2 nanopowder (9 g), attapulgite (4.5 g), SiO2 (1.5 g), LDPE (46 g), LLDPE (22 g), dispersing agent (10 g), lubricant (5 g) and the cross-link reagent (2 g), through a high-speed mixer (SHR5A) for 15 min at 30 C. After air cooling to room temperature, the masterbatch was extruded to pellets using a twin-screw extruder (SHJ-20, Nanjing Guangda Chemical Equipment Co. Ltd, China). In the second extrusion step, 100 g of pellets and 1.23 kg of LDPE granule were immingled for 15 min. Subsequently the compounds were blown into film with a thickness of 100 lm by using a plastic extruder (SJ50 30/FM1300, Dalian Plastic Machine Factory, China). After cooling, the films were used to make antimicrobial nano-silver packaging (ANP) bags with a size of 15 30 cm2 using a heat sealer (SDD-A500/1200, Zhaoyuan Packaging Machiner Co., China). Normal PE packaging (NP) with the same thickness and size without masterbatch served as the control sample.
About 1000 g of the polished rice was randomly packed in ANP (10 bags) and NP (10 bags), which were then sealed and stored at 37 C and relative humidity of 70%. After storage, the rice was ground with a grinder (ZK200) and then sieved through a 40 mesh sieve. Rice flour was collected and analyzed immediately.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization of the antimicrobial nano-silver packaging
sections.text: X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed on a Siemens D5000 diffractometer with CuKa radiation operating at 30 kV and 40 mA.

sections.heading: 2.4. Migration of silver
sections.text:
According to the guidelines that test the migration of constituents of food contact plastics (Regulation 10/2011/EU), 3% (v/ v) aqueous acetic acid (HAc 3%) and 50% (v/v) aqueous ethanol (EtOH 50%) were selected as food simulants at two test conditions: 37 C for 2, 4 and 6 days and 50 C for 1, 2 and 12 h. Determination of Ag was carried out by inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS, Agilent 7500C). Prior to the migration tests, simulants were filtered through a 220 nm Millipore filter and the packaging was digested in the microwave oven (MARS-6). The microwave program for digestion was as follows: the temperature was increased to 120 C in 10 min with the microwave at 1000 W, and then increased to 150 C from 10 to 12 min, and finally held for 25 min at 175 C with the microwave at 1000 W. The tubes were cooled for 1 h, and then the digested solution was diluted with ultrapure water to 10 mL and analyzed by ICP-MS to determine the concentration of Ag in the rice. Each sample was analyzed by triplicate. Samples were introduced to the ICP-MS using a spray chamber (Agilent Technologies). The spray chamber was cooled to 2 C with a Peltier device to ensure stable temperature and reduce the amount of water vapour present in the nebulizer gas flow. Argon was used as the carrier gas. A scandium internal standard solution (1 lg mL 1) was used to optimize the instrument, and was introduced via a peristaltic pump with the sample solution. The ICP-MS operating conditions were as follows: RF power, 1500W; plasma gas flow rate, 13.0 L min 1; auxiliary gas flow rate, 0.7 L min 1; carrier gas flow rate, 1.07 L min 1; and makeup gas flow rate, 1.0 L min 1.The sampling depth was 8.0 mm.
0.1 g of the rice was put into polytetrafluoroethylene tubes and 5 mL of HNO3 was added. The tubes were sealed and the samples were digested and the concentration of silver was tested by ICPMS, and the method described above.

sections.heading: 2.5. Antimicrobial test of films
sections.text: Aspergillus flavus (A. flavus) was selected as a model for Antimicrobial test of ANP and NP films. Before the microbiological experimentation, all glasswares and samples were sterilized by autoclaving at 120 C for 15 min. The antimicrobial test was based on JIS Z 2801-2000 method (antimicrobial plastics-Test for antimicrobial activity and efficacy) with a slight modification. Firstly, the concentration of A. flavus was controlled in 1 105–1 106 CFU mL 1 by the plant count method, and the two samples were cut into the same dimensions of 20 20 mm2. Secondly, 200 lL of A. flavus liquid and 20 mL of liquid Rose Bengal agar were poured onto disposable sterilized Petri dishes, streaked over the plate and spread uniformly, and allowed to solidify. Then, the films were placed over the solidified agar gel in different Petri dishes, and the plates were incubated at 28 C for 5 days. Finally, after drying the films, Scanning electron microscope (TM-3000, Hitachi, Tokyo, Japan) was used to observe the growth of A. flavus on two films at a magnification of 2000 with an accelerating voltage of 25 kV.

sections.heading: 2.6. Antimicrobial activity
sections.text: Rice was analyzed every 7 days after storing. Total plate count (TPC) was examined according to GB/T 4789-2008 (National Standard of China, 2008). The rice (25 g) was put into 225 mL of 0.85% aseptic physiological saline and the mixture was shaken in a stomacher bag (Lab blender 400) for 6 min. The homogenate was serially diluted in 0.85% aseptic physiological saline and 1 mL of the appropriate dilutions were poured and plated onto sterile Rose Bengal Agar (RBA) plate. The plates were then incubated at 28 C for 48 ± 2 h before enumeration.

sections.heading: 2.7. Cooked rice properties
sections.text: The textural profiles of 12 g samples of cooked rice were determined using a texture analyzer (TA-XT2; Stable MicroSystems Ltd., Haslemere, UK). A two-cycle compression, force-versus-distance program was used to allow the plate to travel 9.0 mm, return, and repeat the motion at the same speed. The test speed was 100 mm/s and the probe was 25 mm in diameter. Hardness, adhesiveness, and cohesiveness were recorded.

sections.heading: 2.8. Determination of pasting properties
sections.text: Pasting properties of the flour slurry containing 3.0 g on a dry basis (db) of flour in 25 mL of distilled water were measured by a Rapid Viscosity Analyzer (RVA) (New Port Scientific Instrument and Engineer, Warri water, Australia). The flour dispersion was held at 50 C for 1 min, heated from 50 to 95 C at a heating rate of 12 C/min, held at 95 C for 2.5 min and cooled to 50 C at the same rate. Amylograms describing pasting characteristics included: pasting temperature; peak viscosity; peak time; pasting temperature; breakdown viscosity; final viscosity; and setback value. The RVA measurements were performed in triplicate.

sections.heading: 3.1. XRD
sections.text: Fig. 1 shows XRD patterns of different samples. Ag exhibited cubic phase with peaks at 38.2 , 44.4 , 64.4 , and 77.4 (JCPDS 03-0921). Anatase type structure was observed in nanosized TiO2, and the mean crystalline size was determined to be about 10 nm based on Scherrer’s equation from (101) peak. This finding is in agreement with the model for TiO2 used as precursor. The XRD pattern of ANP shows the characteristic peaks corresponding to TiO2 phase and LDPE as well. A small peak for the rutile phase was also found, which means that the transformation of crystal forms occurs during the processing. However, no characteristic peaks assigned to Ag phase were observed. This indicates that the Ag particles were well dispersed on TiO2 and the particle size was less than 3 nm that the characteristic peak could not be detected. This is in agreement with our previous work (Lambert et al., 2009) where a well-dispersed noble metal on carbon oxide support was produced by classical strong electrostatic adsorption method.

sections.heading: 3.2. Migration of Ag ions
sections.text:
Prior to the migration studies the concentration of Ag in the nano-silver packaging was determined with a concentration of 17.59 mg kg 1. The migration results for Ag are shown in Table 1. For all simulants, the migration of Ag in HAc 3% was higher compared with that in EtOH 50% (Echegoyen & Nerín, 2013). The concentration of Ag in HAc 3% had an increasing trend with the extension of packaging time and the HAc 3% in 50 C had higher Ag concentration. When using EtOH 50% as simulant solution, the migration date had not been detected throughout the experiment. The silver ion release rates increase with temperature and decrease with increasing pH (Liu & Hurt, 2010), that is why the migration values are increased in HAc 3% at 50 C compared with 37 C, and the relatively higher pH leading to no detected Ag in the 50% EtOH. The value that the Ag concentration in packaging at every period was tested and calculated in the same Table. Compared with concentration of silver ion in nano-silver packaging, the concentration of two kind used packaging had dropped to 17.27 and 17.35 mg kg 1. The Ag in nano-silver packaging is released in two way: The first way is to be released into the simulant, and the second way is release into the environment. When the packaging filled with HAc 3% at 50 C, the migration of Ag was higher because HAc 3% dissolved more Ag, leading to the biggest decline of Ag concentration in used packaging that decreased about 1.8%. The concentration of Ag in nano-silver packaging with EtOH 50% decreased by about 1.3%, indicating that most of the Ag had migrated into the environment at 50 C. The comprehensive investigation into the change of Ag concentration into simulants was below the quantification limit, and the Ag/TiO2 powder prepared using a strong electrostatic had a steady quality in packaging. The nano-silver packaging is stable and can release Ag slowly.
Migration is a transfer process that some compounds are released into the environment (Ims & Yoccoz, 1997; Smith, 1988). For ANP, it is necessary to identify the amount of silver in rice at the moment of consumption. The concentration of silver in rice was evaluated every week under the same condition. Fig. 2a shows the concentration of ionic silver in rice at 37 C and relative humidity of 70% as a function of time. It should be noted that Ag+ concentrations for all rice at different times were far below the legal limit. The initial concentration of silver ions in the rice was 0.003 mg/kg. Rice cultivation process and the process of transportation may lead to the high initial concentration. Silver migration was considerably enhanced about 0.0007 mg/kg every week on average. The release rate is low due to the resistance for diffusion of the ions cross the polymeric matrix to the medium (MuñozBonilla & Fernández-García, 2012). Release of silver to rice is one of the important features in ANP, as Ag is an antimicrobial agent, but excessive intake of silver will lead toxicity toward human cells. European Food Safe Authority (EFSA) published a restriction about silver migration into food, and the maximum silver migration is limited to 0.05 mg Ag+/kg of food. The result shows that the
accumulation of Ag on rice was so slow that the average rise was about 1% of legal limit every week, which does not reach the level expected for acute toxic effects on human cells (Le et al., 2010). It is indicated that the ANP has long-term antibacterial activity because of the strong interaction between of Ag and TiO2, which makes Ag released slowly from nano-silver packaging during storage and increases the stability and performance of the inorganic antibacterial packaging as well.

sections.heading: 3.3. Comparison of the antimicrobial activity of the films
sections.text:
The antimicrobial activity of ANP and NP films is shown in Fig. 3. The ANP film effectively inhibited the bacterial growth while the NP film exhibited a lack of antimicrobial activity against A. flavus. SEM images show the growth of A. flavus on the two films. It is shown that the number of A. flavus in NP and ANP films was 70 ± 5 and 5 ± 2, respectively. The gap in bactericidal activity between the two films was more than ten times. The image of the NP (Fig. 3a) illustrated an extremely smooth surface and intensive A. flavus counts. Fig. 3b shows less A. flavus counts and a rough surface because of the presence of Ag/TiO2 and attapulgite. The lower counts in ANP are mostly attributed to the silver ion release process over a long period of time, or direct contact between microorganism and Ag. The antibacterial mechanism of silver nanoparticles is still under debate. Some research suggested Ag/ TiO2 could release small amounts of silver ions, and generate chemical species reactive to oxygen, form complexes with sulfur, nitrogen and oxygen, which damage cell division mechanism and induce the cell death (Matsumura, Yoshikata, Kunisaki, & Tsuchido, 2003). While others reported that silver ions interact with nucleic acids and cytoplasmic component, and chelation by
the thiol group of proteins leading to the alteration of the enzymatic activities (Holt & Bard, 2005). Silver released from nano-silver packaging can interact with the ribosome, and inhibit the expression of enzymes, resulting in membrane permeability of mould. ANP added with Ag/TiO2 nanopowder has strong antimicrobial activity, and packaging rice can reduce the mildew, delaying the deterioration of rice.
The value of mildewmostly caused by mould such as Aspergillus flavus and penicillium, is the major factor in limiting shelf life on rice, leading to the most significant waste of rice worldwide. As shown in Fig. 2b, rice stored with NP showed a serious mildew after one month that TPC increased from 4.84 to 7.15 log cfug 1; while at the same time the rice stored with ANP had a low TPC of 5.48 log cfug 1 after one month. These results indicated that ANP can inhibit these microorganisms. The addition of Ag/TiO2 powder may contribute to the mostly antimicrobial activity of ANP. Photocatalytic reaction may also influence the antimicrobial active under light, where silver ions are in the catalytic activity center to activate water and oxygen in the air to produce hydroxyl free radicals and active oxygen ions (O2 ). Active oxygen ions can destroy the reproductive ability of mould in a short time to induce the cell death.

sections.heading: 3.4. Textural parameters of cooked rice
sections.text:
The textural properties of the cooked rice packed by NP and ANP were determined. Fig. 4a show that the hardness values of samples increased with the storage time. Moreover, the hardness of the rice in ANP became significantly lower compared to the hardness of the rice in normal packaging. With the extension of storage time, the rice starch undergoes fast aging and combines
n NP (a) and ANP (b) films.
with proteins tightly to make the hardness increase. After 28 days, rice deterioration degree deepens that causes an increase in granule swelling and solubility, leading to a decline in hardness. During rice grain aging, there is an increase in the number of disulphide bonds and the high molecular weight peptide subunit of the storage protein oryzenin (Chrastil, 2002; Zarins & Chrastil, 1992), which leads to the changes of the springiness and adhesiveness of cooked rice. Fig. 4b,c show the springiness and adhesiveness of the two cooked rice, revealing a downward trend during storage. The springiness and adhesiveness of the cooked rice packed by normal packaging decreased significantly. Since the antimicrobial activity of nano-materials in the ANP, it can be antibacterial durability, thus maintaining rice texture performance better.

sections.heading: 3.5. Effect of packaging on pasting properties
sections.text:
The changes in the viscosity properties represent sensitive indices in the aging process because they are evident in the storage of rice. Effect of two packagings on the viscosity parameters of rice is summarized in Table 2. Despite being packed with ANP and NP, the pasting temperature and peak time of rice flow were not
altered by accelerated aging. There was an increase in peak viscosity of the two rice storage at a higher temperature. This phenomenon is attributed to a higher resistance and a lower tendency to disrupt the starch granule (Sowbhagya & Bhattacharya, 2001; Tulyathan & Leeharatanaluk, 2007). However, the different responses induced by accelerated aging between rice packed in NP and in ANP on peak viscosity could be due to the barrier of packaging, and TiO2 had a significant effect on the water vapor permeability (Liu et al., 2014), that can retard the change of the pasting properties of rice at storage.
Accelerated aging of rice significantly increased the breakdown viscosity and setback. Breakdown viscosity could reflect the stability of hot paste. The higher breakdown viscosity of rice packed in NP was detected in comparison with the rice packed in ANP due to rearrangement of the grains’ constituents. The setback value mainly resulted from the rearrangement of starch molecules in the system during cooling (Long et al., 2014). A lower setback value for rice packed in NP is shown in comparison with the rice packed in ANP, which is ascribed to the degradation of amylose and long linear amylopectin (Pimpa, Muhammad, Hassan, & Ghazali, 2007). Pasting profiles of rice indicated that the rice packed in

ANP indicate a slower trend comparing with the rice packed in NP. When rice was stored at high temperature and humidity, the microbial growth will accelerate the aging of rice and affect the quality of dried rice. The silver ions can inhibit mould growth and retard the aging of rice. Slower aging of rice gives a slower change of pasting properties. The correlation between the packaging and pasting properties may be due to the antimicrobial properties of ANP, delaying the deterioration of rice, resulting in relatively slow trend.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: Antimicrobial nano-silver packaging containing masterbatch with Ag/TiO2 nanopowder has been produced. Owing to the strong electrostatic adsorption that exists between the Ag precursor and the TiO2, well-dispersed Ag particles on TiO2are obtained during the preparation process. The small amount of migration of silver from the ANP films can inhibit the A. flavus significantly and reduce the mildew of rice during storage. Changes in physicochemical properties and the degree of mildew of rice apparently occur during storage under the hot and humid condition, and packaging material ANP plays an important role for the rice aging process. ANP is proven to be efficient for retarding the changes of pasting qualities and texture, and extending shelf life. Therefore, ANP is a promising packaging material for rice storage against environment.

sections.text: C.C. thanks fund from the Natural Science Foundation of Jiangsu Province (BK20141486), the funding from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 31571901) and the Priority Academic Program Development of Jiangsu Higher Education Institutions.

referenceMentions.context: To sustain consumer demand throughout the whole year or in case of emergency, a certain quantity of harvesting rice should be stored (Choi et al., 2015).
Many studies have been reported on the change in pasting properties, texture characteristic, nutrition and flavor of aged rice (Champagne et al., 1998; Zhou, Robards, Helliwell, & Blanchard, 2003).

In recent years, nanocomposite food packages produced by incorporating nanoparticles of metal and meal oxide including silver, zinc oxide, titania and alumina (Llorens, Lloret, Picouet, Trbojevich, & Fernandez, 2012), have been used in several agricultural products (Abreu, Cruz, Angulo, & Losada, 2010), such as mushroom (Fang et al., 2015) and strawberry (Yang et al.
In recent years, great attention has been devoted to nanomaterials owing to their unique impact on a wide range of industries and markets (Pitkethly, 2004).
It is commonly used in packaging as a photocatalytic antibacterial agent (Dariusz et al., 2007; Salabat, 2015; Zhou, Robards, Helliwell, & Blanchard, 2002).

Ag/TiO2 powder was prepared using a strong electrostatic adsorption method (Lambert et al., 2009).
Migration is a transfer process that some compounds are released into the environment (Ims & Yoccoz, 1997; Smith, 1988).
accumulation of Ag on rice was so slow that the average rise was about 1% of legal limit every week, which does not reach the level expected for acute toxic effects on human cells (Le et al., 2010).

During rice grain aging, there is an increase in the number of disulphide bonds and the high molecular weight peptide subunit of the storage protein oryzenin (Chrastil, 2002; Zarins & Chrastil, 1992), which leads to the changes of the springiness and adhesiveness of cooked rice.

However, the different responses induced by accelerated aging between rice packed in NP and in ANP on peak viscosity could be due to the barrier of packaging, and TiO2 had a significant effect on the water vapor permeability (Liu et al., 2014), that can retard the change of the pasting properties of rice at storage.
The setback value mainly resulted from the rearrangement of starch molecules in the system during cooling (Long et al., 2014).

metadata.abstractText: Antimicrobial nano-silver packaging (ANP) films were synthesized by blending polyethylene and highly dispersed Ag/TiO2 powder for rice storage at 37 C and 70% relative humidity. ANP films were characterized by X-ray diffraction and silver migration. The antimicrobial activity of the films was assessed on Aspergillus flavus (A. flavus) by scanning electron microscope and total plate count, and the storage quality of rice was evaluated by texture analyzer and rapid viscosity analyzer. The results show that ANP had a quite beneficial effect on the antimildew and physicochemical property as compared to the normal PE packaging. During 35 days storage, the migration of silver into rice was not evident. A lower microbial population is observed on ANP that should be attributed to the presence of Ag/TiO2. Furthermore, rice packed by ANP shows an enhanced quality with regards to texture and pasting properties. Therefore, ANP is a promising packaging material for rice storage. 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
